title: @Riot How do you catalog the strengths and weaknesses of a champion?
body:
Once a character has hit the ground, be it in internal alpha, PBE, or live, how do you keep track of the peaks and valleys of a character's game play? How do you present these things for you or someone else to digest and how do you archive it so that certain issues are accessible? 
There's a character that has less counterplay than I'd like and has few meaningful fallback strategies when doing poorly. How do you communicate those issues to other designers on the project in reference form (i.e. documentation) so the problem is always clear?

While I'm at it, do you feel that every champ needs a fallback strategy. Why or why not? I've read that you consider Yasuo a well designed champ in terms of the "levers" that can be pulled to keep him in line while also having a strong defensive tool (his Wind Wall) to keep him relevant in teamfights when he's doing poorly. Does every champ need this or should certain champs stay behind if they don't secure an early lead?

Finally, what are ways in which you attempt to create counterplay where there's very little?

replies.body:
Internally we work with a combination of documented strengths/weaknesses, both in terms of intention and observed, that are kept in a shared file on a per champion basis, and a bunch of discussion/consensus building. Generally we're focused on the conceptual level (e.g. Braum should be strong against ranged threats and work well with auto attacking allies, weaker against divers etc). That's all very much a perpetual work in progress, not a rigid locked down set of laws  though of course. As new information comes in, from player discovery, changes to game systems/meta etc it's often necessary to revisit existing assumptions and then sometimes adjust the approach you'd been taking.

Fall back patterns are something we generally want to offer to champions. Being behind should put you at a significant disadvantage, but shouldn't effectively remove you from the game. There are some champions where that's not really the case and that's something that's occasionally worth tolerating if it lets you do enough other valuable things with the character (game design's a series of trade offs basically).

Adding counterplay's all about giving other players ways to interact with a skill, champion or whatever. Some of the most common approaches we'll look at include range limits or changing abilities to skillshots (positional counterplay), requiring buildup or expenditure to use abilities (resource costs, whether mana, buff building, ammo etc), substantial CDs (windows of strength and vulnerability), dependency on other elements like extra enemies/other allied champs etc.

>Fall back patterns are something we generally want to offer to champions. Being behind should put you at a significant disadvantage, but shouldn't effectively remove you from the game.

Most ADC champions would like to have a work with you as would a few champs facing certain counterpicks.

Having a fall back pattern doesn't mean you're still really effective regardless of your past performance that game, but that there's some way you can continue to play and be useful if you get sufficiently far behind you can't perform your normal actions successfully. For ADCs that often comes via poke to harass/still farm somewhat (e.g. Ezreal, Kog, Corki, Jinx, Lucian) and/or spell based contributions that aren't too dependent on game performance (e.g. Ashe and Varus especially, Jinx, MF to lesser degrees). Some ADCs do have much weaker fallback patterns certainly and that's one of the risks you take when picking them (Vayne and Draven for example). 

Counterpicks can invalidate a champion's primary playstyle and, especially if they don't have a fallback pattern to shift to, potentially shut them down really hard. Late game that's not such an issue, since LoL's a team game where your allies can cover for your weaknesses and there are other enemies to focus instead, early game (laning) however that can be pretty game deciding, hence our desire to avoid hard counterpicks in the early game. Are there particular champion match ups you have in mind as major problems?

One series of match-ups people will probably cite here is anything melee vs Ryze in top lane - the early game of which was rightfully nerfed.

However, Ryze does feel (and fare) a lot worse now in the late-game, too, due to losing 40 damage per Q without compensation in increased (AP) scaling.

Yeah, Ryze's combination of high reliability, tankiness and eventually really high sustained damage isn't something we're happy with, given it leaves some opponents without valid options against him. Short term we've taken some power out of him as a result, longer term we're going to rework a skill or two to address those core problems (which will probably mean we can then put at least some of that damage back in).

Which part of the kit would such a rework entail, in your personal eyes? From his animation and feeling side, skillshottifying Q or E would make the most sense, as both spells are already working like Ryze throwing a projectile.

Side note - Katarina Q, as a skillshot. Would that make sense/feel good? Especially since there is this coding "feature", where it currently has the ability to block certain skillshots like Morgana's Q if both projectiles collide - I wonder if that is a functionality you at Riot could embrace for a short-range, fast-moving, fast animation skillshot.
Whoa, whoa, whoa... you mean he will actually require some "Skill" shots. :D

I think Ryze is pretty much overrated though, he is incredible vulnerable to all-ins early on. Most people just get shocked by his burst and then fall back and lose the trade instead of going deep and killing him/forcing him away. There are way worse offenders.

basically Renekton can't touch him when ranged and it's suicide to fight him when melee

I have one. Rumble is a hard, HARD counterpick to Malphite.

>Are there particular champion match ups you have in mind as major problems?

A good place to look for this is popular guides that list matchups.  However since you asked an example as someone who wants to play Poppy, I know I can't take her top in a lot of matchups just because she loses hard to most ranged tops as well as other popular melee tops (irelia, darius, maybe renekton).  This is why she's becoming more of a jungler of late... she's so easy to counterpick up top it isn't funny as well as being a great duelist in the jungle.

Depending on who use ask, she might have 6-8 hard counterpicks up top for the early game.  Now yes she makes up for it with the late game, but by then it might be over.  

Don't get me wrong, her late game potential is part of the reason a lot of people love her and in her upcoming rework she needs to keep that endgame terror status, but her early game is the worst in a lot of situations.

>Fall back patterns are something we generally want to offer to champions. Being behind should put you at a significant disadvantage, but shouldn't effectively remove you from the game. There are some champions where that's not really the case and that's something that's occasionally worth tolerating if it lets you do enough other valuable things with the character (game design's a series of trade offs basically).

I think you need to look at itemization then. It's especially evident with ADCs, but AP mids also have the same problem. If one ADC goes back at 1400 gold and buys a pickaxe and boots, and the other goes back at 1600 gold and buys a BF Sword, the latter is guaranteed to win the lane unless they screw up massively. (For ap mids, replace 'pickaxe' with 'blasting wand' and 'BF sword' with 'Needlessly Large Rod'). 200 gold should not dictate the lane.

>Adding counterplay's all about giving other players ways to interact with a skill, champion or whatever. Some of the most common approaches we'll look at include range limits or changing abilities to skillshots (positional counterplay), requiring buildup or expenditure to use abilities (resource costs, whether mana, buff building, ammo etc), substantial CDs (windows of strength and vulnerability), dependency on other elements like extra enemies/other allied champs etc.

I think there's one thing that Riot keeps forgetting: making something a skillshot provides 'counterplay', yes, but it also removes 'counterplay' from the person using it. Consider how many dashes are in the game; the incredibly slippery champs like Yasuo or Fizz. You need targetted CC with those guys because skillshots are difficult/impossible to land. Therefore, making more abilities skillshots just makes 'mobile in a fight' champions that much stronger.

> I think you need to look at itemization then. It's especially evident with ADCs, but AP mids also have the same problem. If one ADC goes back at 1400 gold and buys a pickaxe and boots, and the other goes back at 1600 gold and buys a BF Sword, the latter is guaranteed to win the lane unless they screw up massively. (For ap mids, replace 'pickaxe' with 'blasting wand' and 'BF sword' with 'Needlessly Large Rod'). 200 gold should not dictate the lane.

Actually, yes, it should. If you have to back with less than the threshold amount for your next powerspike, it either means that your opponent played really well in forcing you back (and hence should be rewarded) or you made mistakes (and hence should be punished). These mistakes could be to miss too much CS, position wrongly for CS, or to outright go for a bad trade.

There's a difference between 'you're getting punished for making mistakes' and 'you just lost your lane'.

There's not fallback mechanism there besides trying to avoid fights and farming.

What other fallback mechanism should there be? You know you're in a disadvantaged position - deal with it. You try to sit back, farm, avoid disadvantageous fights and try to capitalize on your opponents' mistakes. If you're lucky or have a competent jungler, he will come around and help you out.

Especially since a Pickaxe isn't a dead-end item for you - as a competent AD carry, you'll have two in your completed item's build paths anyway. And being faster than the enemy should help you with avoiding those bad fights, too.

It basically ensues that the opponent will always have better farm than you (because they have easier last hitting and more lane pressure), which means they can get to the 1100ish gold to get to the items you bought easier. Meanwhile, you're already in a bad position, and you have to wait until 1550 gold in order to buy your next important thing. You don't get to say 'okay, I'm behind, I'll just buy a less expensive item first in order to get that smaller powerspike earlier.' An early LW doesn't mean much on most ADCs (though Varus might be able to swing it), and you can't just decide to start building a BoRK or TF instead, because there ain't a pickaxe in those. You can't build attack speed first unless you're Vayne or maybe Kog. You just desperately have to hope that your jungler decides your lane worth saving and for the rest of your lanes to do decently. 

Compare this to AP mids. Sure, if you're really ahead and snowballing, you can just buy a rod, but you don't need to do that. You could go for a chalice for the sustain, or an Armguard against an ad mid, or a haunting guise for early mag pen. They have better options for in lane itemization if they're behind. They gate the 'you are now relevant!' part of being an ADC behind a 1550 gold item, and if you can't rush that item, you're screwed.

> I think there's one thing that Riot keeps forgetting: making something a skillshot provides 'counterplay', yes, but it also removes 'counterplay' from the person using it. Consider how many dashes are in the game; the incredibly slippery champs like Yasuo or Fizz. You need targetted CC with those guys because skillshots are difficult/impossible to land. Therefore, making more abilities skillshots just makes 'mobile in a fight' champions that much stronger.
